awd_titl_txt: Direct and Inverse Electromagnetic Scattering Problems for Complex Periodic Media
awd_abstract_narration:
The interaction and scattering of light by periodic structures at the nanoscale 
is a topic of great significance in the area of nanophotonics and metamaterials 
technology. With the current rapid development of this enabling technology, there 
is a high demand on new mathematical theories and computational algorithms 
for both direct and inverse problems of the light scattering by periodic complex 
media or periodic metamaterials. This project aims to develop such theories 
and algorithms. Results from this project will advance knowledge, understanding 
and imaging techniques in the technology of nanophotonics and metamaterials. 
For instance, the mathematical theories and the computational algorithms developed 
for the direct problems are extremely useful for the simulation, fabrication and 
maintaining of optical devices. The imaging techniques developed for the inverse 
problems can be potentially of practical use for non-destructive tests, which help 
to detect and characterize discrete flaws in optical components and devices.

The project contains two main areas of study: the mathematical and numerical 
analysis for direct scattering problems, and the development of efficient inversion 
algorithms for inverse scattering problems. More precisely, for the direct problem, 
the PI and his colleagues will work on the following topics: 1) develop volume integral 
equation formulations for direct scattering problems for periodic complex media; 2) 
develop fast integral equation-based numerical solvers for the direct scattering problems; 
3) study interior transmission eigenvalues for periodic complex media; 4) study 
well-posedness of the scattering by chiral metamaterials. The proposed research 
for the inverse problem includes the topics: 1) develop sampling methods 
for imaging of periodic complex  media; 2) develop sampling methods for the detection 
of local defects in photonic crystals; 3) develop globally convergent methods for 
the identification of material parameters for photonic crystals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The direct and inverse scattering of electromagnetic waves by complex and periodic media have important applications in optics and nanophotonics. The project comprises two main areas of study: the mathematical and numerical analysis for direct scattering problems, and the development of efficient inversion algorithms for solving inverse scattering problems. These studies have a direct impact on the field of computational and applied mathematics, particularly in the areas of computational inverse problems and imaging, numerical analysis, and scientific computing. Additionally, the theory and the numerical solvers developed for the direct problems can be useful for the simulation, fabrication, and maintenance of optical devices. The inversion methods can potentially be of practical use for non-destructive tests, which help to detect and characterize discrete flaws in optical components and devices. Specific outcomes of the project include the following.

1) We established the well-posedness of the direct electromagnetic scattering problem for bi-anisotropic and chiral media via an integrodifferential equation approach. We developed a spectral Galerkin method with a rigorous convergence analysis to numerically solve the integrodifferential equation for the direct scattering problem.

2) We studied the factorization method for the inverse electromagnetic scattering problem for anisotropic and bi-anisotropic periodic media. We established a rigorous justification of the method which leads to unique determination results and fast numerical reconstruction algorithms for the inverse problem. 

3) We developed orthogonality sampling methods for the inverse electromagnetic scattering problem for magnetically anisotropic media and bi-anisotropic media. The sampling methods are very simple to implement and stable against noise in the data. In particular, these methods were tested on the 3D experimental data from the Fresnel Institute. 

4) We studied globally convergent methods to reconstruct material parameters in inverse scattering problems. These methods are able to compute the material parameter of the scattering medium without using any advanced a priori information about the parameter.

The project also had a significant impact on training graduate and undergraduate researchers. Two Ph.D. students and eight undergraduate students completed research projects directly related to this grant. The PI lectured in a summer school on inverse problems in imaging for graduate students on the research supported by this grant. The results of the project were published in ten mathematics journal articles and reported by the PI and his graduate and undergraduate students (over forty five talks and poster presentations) at many seminars, workshops, and conferences.
